clusters.title: Iran warns 'fully prepared for war' if US intervenes as protests enter third week
clusters.neutral_headline: Iran’s FM says protests became ‘bloody’ to give Trump intervention excuse

items.title: Iran warns 'fully prepared for war' if US intervenes as protests enter third week
items.standfirst: U.S. President Donald Trump says Iran has proposed negotiations after his threat to strike the Islamic Republic as an ongoing crackdown on demonstrators has led to hundreds of deaths. But while Iran says it is ready for negotiations based on 'mutual respect', it has warned it is 'fully prepared for war'. In the meantime, the son of the ousted shah syas he is 'prepared to return' - something that looks easier said than done. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle tells us more as protests enter their third week.
items.content: U.S. President Donald Trump says Iran has proposed negotiations after his threat to strike the Islamic Republic as an ongoing crackdown on demonstrators has led to hundreds of deaths. But while Iran says it is ready for negotiations based on 'mutual respect', it has warned it is 'fully prepared for war'. In the meantime, the son of the ousted shah syas he is 'prepared to return' - something that looks easier said than done. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle tells us more as protests enter their third week.

items.content: President weighs potential intervention in Islamic republic amid intensifying crackdown

items.title: Iran’s FM says protests became ‘bloody’ to give Trump intervention excuse

items.content: Iranian media report a calm night as a nationwide internet ban continues and US president announces a possible meeting.

items.title: Trump warns of “very strong options” amid Iran unrest
items.standfirst: Trump said the US is considering “very strong options,” over the deaths of protesters in Iran.
items.content: Trump said the US is considering “very strong options,” over the deaths of protesters in Iran.

items.title: Trump says Iran wants to negotiate as the death toll in protests rises
items.standfirst: President Trump said Sunday that Iran wants to negotiate with Washington after his threat to strike the Islamic Republic over its bloody crackdown on protesters.
items.content: President Trump said Sunday that Iran wants to negotiate with Washington after his threat to strike the Islamic Republic over its bloody crackdown on protesters.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Live: Iran open to negotiations with US based on ‘mutual respect’, foreign minister says
items.standfirst: Iran is ready to negotiate with the United States, its foreign minister said Monday, but stressed that any such talks would have to be “fair” and based on “mutual respect”. The comments come after US President Donald Trump said Tehran was seeking negotiations following his threat that Washington could intervene militarily if Iranian authorities killed protesters. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.
items.content: Iran is ready to negotiate with the United States, its foreign minister said Monday, but stressed that any such talks would have to be “fair” and based on “mutual respect”. The comments come after US President Donald Trump said Tehran was seeking negotiations following his threat that Washington could intervene militarily if Iranian authorities killed protesters. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

items.title: Trump mulls 'very strong' military options as hundreds killed in Iran protests
items.standfirst: The US president says Iranian leaders have called "to negotiate", but adds the US "may have to act" before a meeting.
items.content: The US president says Iranian leaders have called "to negotiate", but adds the US "may have to act" before a meeting.

items.title: Trump says he is considering ‘very strong’ military options against Iran as protester death toll climbs
items.standfirst: US president claims ‘Iran wants to negotiate’ as rights groups report that regime’s crackdown on protest has killed hundreds Donald Trump has claimed Iran has reached out and proposed negotiations, as he considers “very strong” military action against the regime over a deadly crackdown on protesters that has reportedly killed hundreds.Asked on Sunday by reporters aboard Air Force One if Iran had crossed his previously stated red line of protesters being killed, Trump said “they’re starting to, it looks like.” Continue reading...
items.content: US president claims ‘Iran wants to negotiate’ as rights groups report that regime’s crackdown on protest has killed hundreds Donald Trump has claimed Iran has reached out and proposed negotiations, as he considers “very strong” military action against the regime over a deadly crackdown on protesters that has reportedly killed hundreds.Asked on Sunday by reporters aboard Air Force One if Iran had crossed his previously stated red line of protesters being killed, Trump said “they’re starting to, it looks like.” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says US considering ‘very strong options’ for Iran
items.standfirst: US president says Washington is closely monitoring protests in Iran and considering possible military intervention.
items.content: US president says Washington is closely monitoring protests in Iran and considering possible military intervention.

items.title: 500+ killed as Iran cracks down on protesters & issues threat to U.S.
items.standfirst: Hundreds of thousands protest in Iran as government forces mobilize to stop the demonstrations. Human rights activists say more than 500 people have been killed in the last two weeks. The head of the Iranian parliament issued a new warning to the U.S., vowing to strike back if the Trump administration takes military action inside Iran. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez reports.
items.content: Hundreds of thousands protest in Iran as government forces mobilize to stop the demonstrations. Human rights activists say more than 500 people have been killed in the last two weeks. The head of the Iranian parliament issued a new warning to the U.S., vowing to strike back if the Trump administration takes military action inside Iran. NBC News’ Raf Sanchez reports.

items.title: More than 500 killed in Iran, rights group says, as Trump and US military weighing 'strong options'
items.standfirst: The number of people killed in anti-government protests across Iran has risen dramatically to more than 500, according to the US-based Human Rights Activists News Agency.
items.content: The number of people killed in anti-government protests across Iran has risen dramatically to more than 500, according to the US-based Human Rights Activists News Agency.

items.content: President Donald Trump has been weighing a range of options against Iran amid the country’s crackdown on protesters that human rights groups say has killed more than 500 people

items.title: America's top central banker Powell targeted by federal probe
items.standfirst: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell is under criminal investigation by the Justice Department, a probe he calls a "pretext" amid a pressure campaign by President Donald Trump to cut interest rates. Also in this edition: Germany's chancellor travels to India to boost trade ties as exports to China slump.

Also in this edition: Germany's chancellor travels to India to boost trade ties as exports to China slump.

items.title: Justice Dept. served subpoenas to the Fed, Powell says
items.standfirst: The subpoenas threatened a criminal indictment related to Jerome Powell's testimony before the Senate Banking Committee in June 2025, according to the Fed chair.
items.content: The subpoenas threatened a criminal indictment related to Jerome Powell's testimony before the Senate Banking Committee in June 2025, according to the Fed chair.

items.title: Justice department opens investigation into Jerome Powell as Trump ramps up campaign against Federal Reserve
items.standfirst: Fed chair accuses DoJ of threatening criminal charges over building renovation projects because central bank defied Trump’s interest rate demandsThe Department of Justice has opened a criminal investigation into Jerome Powell and the Federal Reserve, a significant escalation in Donald Trump’s extraordinary attack on the US central bank.Powell said the Department of Justice had served the Fed with grand jury subpoenas on Friday, threatening a criminal indictment related to his testimony before the Senate banking committee in June last year, regarding renovations to the Fed’s historic office buildings in Washington DC. Continue reading...
items.content: Fed chair accuses DoJ of threatening criminal charges over building renovation projects because central bank defied Trump’s interest rate demandsThe Department of Justice has opened a criminal investigation into Jerome Powell and the Federal Reserve, a significant escalation in Donald Trump’s extraordinary attack on the US central bank.Powell said the Department of Justice had served the Fed with grand jury subpoenas on Friday, threatening a criminal indictment related to his testimony before the Senate banking committee in June last year, regarding renovations to the Fed’s historic office buildings in Washington DC. Continue reading...

items.content: The Justice Department has subpoenaed the Fed over chair Jerome Powell's testimony over the central bank's headquarters renovation. Powell calls it part of a pressure campaign over interest rates. (Image credit: Andre Caballero-Reynolds)

items.title: Trump’s Justice Department subpoenas Fed Chair Powell, threatens criminal charges
items.standfirst: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said on Sunday the Department of Justice had subpoenaed the central bank and threatened criminal charges over his testimony on Fed building renovations, marking an unprecedented escalation in President Donald Trump’s dispute with the independent Federal Reserve.
items.content: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said on Sunday the Department of Justice had subpoenaed the central bank and threatened criminal charges over his testimony on Fed building renovations, marking an unprecedented escalation in President Donald Trump’s dispute with the independent Federal Reserve.

clusters.title: Anti-ICE pins worn by celebrities at Golden Globes ceremony
clusters.neutral_headline: One Battle After Another, Adolescence dominate Golden Globes

items.title: Anti-ICE pins worn by celebrities at Golden Globes ceremony
items.standfirst: Some celebrities like Mark Ruffalo, Wanda Sykes and Natasha Lyonne donned anti-ICE pins at the Golden Globes on January 11 in tribute to Renee Good, who was shot and killed in her car by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer a few days earlier in Minneapolis. The ceremony crowned the success of the revolutionary comedy "One Battle After Another". FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet tells us about what to expect from this year's awards season.
items.content: Some celebrities like Mark Ruffalo, Wanda Sykes and Natasha Lyonne donned anti-ICE pins at the Golden Globes on January 11 in tribute to Renee Good, who was shot and killed in her car by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer a few days earlier in Minneapolis. The ceremony crowned the success of the revolutionary comedy "One Battle After Another". FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet tells us about what to expect from this year's awards season.

items.title: Chalamet wins best actor at Golden Globes as awards season kicks off
items.standfirst: Dark comedy "One Battle After Another" and "Hamnet," a story about ⁠William Shakespeare's grief over the death of his son, claimed the top prizes on January 11, 2026 at the Golden Globes. The ceremony is one of the first major ones in Hollywood's annual awards season, a season that is expected to be shaped by a battle between the two films. FRANCE 24's Emma Jones tells us more about what to know from the night.
items.content: Dark comedy "One Battle After Another" and "Hamnet," a story about ⁠William Shakespeare's grief over the death of his son, claimed the top prizes on January 11, 2026 at the Golden Globes. The ceremony is one of the first major ones in Hollywood's annual awards season, a season that is expected to be shaped by a battle between the two films. FRANCE 24's Emma Jones tells us more about what to know from the night.

items.title: Chalamet clinches first Golden Globe, 'One Battle After Another' among top winners
items.standfirst: Actor Timothée Chalamet won the Golden Globe for best actor in a comedy film on Sunday, a potential boost to his Oscar prospects, as "One Battle After Another" took multiple honours. Chalamet, previously winless after four Globe nominations, was applauded by fellow nominees including Leonardo DiCaprio and George Clooney.
items.content: Actor Timothée Chalamet won the Golden Globe for best actor in a comedy film on Sunday, a potential boost to his Oscar prospects, as "One Battle After Another" took multiple honours. Chalamet, previously winless after four Globe nominations, was applauded by fellow nominees including Leonardo DiCaprio and George Clooney.

items.title: Avalanche kills British skier in La Plagne in the French Alps
items.standfirst: Man, thought to be in his 50s, was found under 2.5 metres of snow and had been skiing off-pisteA British skier has been killed by an avalanche in the French Alps.The man, believed to be in his 50s, was found under 2.5 metres of snow after a 50-minute search, a statement from the La Plagne resort in south-eastern France said. clusters.title: U.S. launches retaliatory strikes against ISIS in Syria, officials say
clusters.neutral_headline: US military strikes Islamic State group targets in Syria, officials say

items.title: U.S. launches retaliatory strikes against ISIS in Syria, officials say
items.standfirst: The U.S. military struck multiple locations in Syria to target ISIS on Saturday, according to the Central Command. It came as Syria announced a ceasefire with Kurdish fighters after three days of clashes in the north. This is the second time the U.S. has struck ISIS in response to the deadly attack on U.S. and Syrian forces in Palmyra last month.
items.content: The U.S. military struck multiple locations in Syria to target ISIS on Saturday, according to the Central Command. It came as Syria announced a ceasefire with Kurdish fighters after three days of clashes in the north. This is the second time the U.S. has struck ISIS in response to the deadly attack on U.S. and Syrian forces in Palmyra last month.

items.title: U.S. carries out new strikes against ISIS targets in Syria
items.standfirst: The U.S. carried out strikes against Islamic State targets across Syria, U.S. Central Command announced. This comes nearly one month after two American soldiers and a civilian interpreter were killed by an ISIS ambush in Palmyra, Syria.

items.title: What we know about the deadly anti-regime protests in Iran
items.standfirst: Iran has been rocked by nationwide demonstrations for the past two weeks. What began as anger over the country’s ailing economy quickly escalated into violent – even deadly – anti-regime protests, prompting the regime to shut down communications networks. Here is what we know about the unrest.

clusters.title: US ramps up pressure on Cuba after Maduro capture
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump tells Cuba to ‘make a deal’ or face the consequences

items.title: US ramps up pressure on Cuba after Maduro capture
items.standfirst: The US President Donald Trump is urging Cuba to "make a deal" or face unspecified consequences. The Communist-run Caribbean nation was defiant responding that no one tells it what to do. Although has imposed economy-crippling sanctions on Cuba for decades, Trump has ramped up the pressure in recent days, since Nicolas Maduro's dramatic capture.
items.content: The US President Donald Trump is urging Cuba to "make a deal" or face unspecified consequences. The Communist-run Caribbean nation was defiant responding that no one tells it what to do. Although has imposed economy-crippling sanctions on Cuba for decades, Trump has ramped up the pressure in recent days, since Nicolas Maduro's dramatic capture.

items.title: Trump tells Cuba to ‘make a deal’ or face the consequences
items.standfirst: No more Venezuelan oil or money will flow to the communist-run island after Maduro’s fall, says US presidentDonald Trump has told Cuba to “make a deal” or face unspecified consequences, adding that no more Venezuelan oil or money would flow to the communist-run Caribbean island that has been a US foe for decades.As Cuba, a close ally of Venezuela and big beneficiary of its oil, braced for potential widespread unrest after Nicolás Maduro was deposed as the South American nation’s leader, the US president ramped up his threatening language on Sunday. Continue reading...

items.title: Torq hits $1.2bn valuation for agentic AI-driven security platform
items.standfirst: Torq, an Israeli company specialising in agentic AI-driven security operations, has successfully secured $140m in Series D funding, raising its valuation to $1.2bn. The funding round was led by cybersecurity fund Merlin Ventures. It also had participation from existing investors such as Evolution…

clusters.title: Trump threatens to block ExxonMobil from Venezuela after CEO calls country ‘uninvestable’
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump threatens to block Exxon from Venezuela

items.title: Trump threatens to block ExxonMobil from Venezuela after CEO calls country ‘uninvestable’
items.standfirst: US president says company is ‘playing too cute’ after CEO responds sceptically to his push for oil investment after deposing Nicolás MaduroDonald Trump has said he might block ExxonMobil from investing in Venezuela after the oil company’s chief executive called the country “uninvestable” during a White House meeting last week.Darren Woods told the US president that Venezuela would need to change its laws before it could be an attractive investment opportunity, during the high-profile meeting on Friday with at least 17 other oil executives. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.neutral_headline: Denmark’s PM says Greenland showdown at ‘decisive moment’

items.title: Denmark’s PM says Greenland showdown at ‘decisive moment’
items.standfirst: Denmark is ready to defend its values, Mette Frederiksen says, as Trump renews threats to seize the Danish territory.
items.content: Denmark is ready to defend its values, Mette Frederiksen says, as Trump renews threats to seize the Danish territory.

items.title: PM says Denmark faces ‘decisive moment’ as Trump renews threat of force over Greenland
items.standfirst: Denmark’s Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said on Sunday her country faced a “decisive moment” in its diplomatic dispute with the United States over Greenland, after Donald Trump again suggested using force to seize the Arctic territory. Speaking ahead of meetings in Washington on raw materials, Frederiksen said “there is a conflict over Greenland”.
items.content: Denmark’s Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said on Sunday her country faced a “decisive moment” in its diplomatic dispute with the United States over Greenland, after Donald Trump again suggested using force to seize the Arctic territory. Speaking ahead of meetings in Washington on raw materials, Frederiksen said “there is a conflict over Greenland”.

clusters.title: Sudan's government returns to capital after nearly 3 years of war
clusters.neutral_headline: Sudan's government returns to capital after nearly 3 years of war

items.title: Sudan's government returns to capital after nearly 3 years of war
items.standfirst: The military-backed government is back in Khartoum after being driven out by its paramilitary rival.
items.content: The military-backed government is back in Khartoum after being driven out by its paramilitary rival.

items.title: Sudan PM announces govt's return to Khartoum from wartime capital Port Sudan
items.standfirst: The Sudanese government which had been driven out by war has returned to Khartoum and promises “better services” for the capital's residents, Prime Minister Kamil Idris announced on Sunday. The army-aligned government had been operating out of its wartime capital of Port Sudan for nearly three years after it had been driven out of Khartoum by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces.
items.content: The Sudanese government which had been driven out by war has returned to Khartoum and promises “better services” for the capital's residents, Prime Minister Kamil Idris announced on Sunday. The army-aligned government had been operating out of its wartime capital of Port Sudan for nearly three years after it had been driven out of Khartoum by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces.
